title: Projectile Motion
content:
Projectile Motion

The Hook

When a cricket fielder throws the ball back to the wicketkeeper, the ball traces a curved path through the air. Why does it curve? This beautiful arc is called projectile motion!

The Concept

A projectile is any object thrown into the air that moves under gravity alone (no engine). Its motion is a combination of two independent motions: horizontal (constant velocity) and vertical (constant acceleration downward due to gravity, g ≈ 10 m/s²). The result is a curved path called a parabola.

The Illustration

Imagine tossing a tiffin box horizontally off a table. Horizontally, it travels at constant speed. Vertically, it falls faster and faster. Both happen simultaneously, creating the curve. A javelin athlete, a basketball player, or the legendary Sachin hitting a six — all rely on projectile physics to perfect their technique!
